title: How many U.S. states will have a 1.0 or greater effective reproduction number (Rt) for COVID-19 as of 11 January 2021?
preds: This is an easy prediction so close to the cut-off -- very unlikely that less than 23 States will have a Rt less than 1.0 even if the trend of infection will likely change to downward in the next 6 weeks.

Since my first forecast on 1/1:
Rt<1.0 - 9 (was 12) - of which 3 are at .98-.99 and another 3 are .96-.97
Rt 1.0 - 1.04 - 13 (holding at 13)
Rt 1.05 - 1.09 - 13 (was 16)
Rt >=1.10 - 16 (was 10)  With 4 days to go it is extremely unlikely that any of the >=1.05 will drop below 1.00. Most drops are .01 per day and judging by the nature of the 51 curves, I see a minimum of 30 states >=1.00 even if some states that seem to be on the downswing get under 1.00.
Forecasters who have written a rational and who have an anteriority on the site are more pessimistic than my last prediction, which I therefore align with theirs.

In 3 days since my last prediction, the number of states is stable at more than 40. I don't think the situation will change in 5 days in more than 20 states.
So I decrease the probability of a number lower than 23 but still not zero, because the decrease in Rt in 9 days can be rapid since Rt>1 has increased in a few days from 23 states to over 40.
Numbers should go up now that the holiday season is over and testing starts to go up again.
With the new more infectious strain on the loose and the slow rollout of the vaccines, I don't think there is much chance of the Rt rate being below 1.0 for less than 24 states by 11 Jan.

1/3 there are 41 states ABOVE the threshold.
GAME OVER
42 on Jan 2; unlikely to go below 23 by Jan 11.

In 3 days since my last prediction, the number of states has risen from 23 to more than 40, surely due to the gatherings related to the end of year festivities.
Within 11 days where there should be no more massive gatherings, and where vaccination will not yet be massively deployed, there will surely be a decrease in Rt in several states. The decrease in Rt in 9 days can be rapid since Rt>1 has increased in a few days from 23 states to over 40.
So I decrease the probability of a number lower than 23 but still not zero.
I also adhere to the rational of @ray-wallin  which goes in the same direction.

As of 1/1/21 there are 39 states with Rt>=1.0; Most states appear to be holding steady or rising over the two week period (including those with a RT<1.0).  Given the holiday reporting lag after two "long" weekends, I suspect there will be an increase in reported cases that will push the numbers upward plus the impacts of gatherings from both Christmas and New Years. While it is possible for the Rt to drop over the course of the next 9 days, It is unlikely that many states will see a big enough swing to get under 1.0. As of 1/1/21:
Rt<1.0 - 12 (only 4 are in the .98 to .99 range)
Rt 1.0 - 1.04 - 13 (possible to get below 1)
Rt 1.05 - 1.09 - 16 (not likely to get below 1)
Rt >=1.10 - 10 (very unlikely to get below 1) If you take the last two groups 10 that are surely staying about 1.0; 16 which are likely above 1.0; and couple in the states showing increases that are borderline (below 1.0 or between 1.0 and 1.04) the outlook points to >=23 states remaining above 1.0 on 1/11/21.
The holidaymakers started testing positive earlier than I expected; the numbers should hold up for the first couple of weeks in January.

Today: 23
2weeks ago:22
1month ago:28
2 months ago: 49
3 months ago: 51
=>during the 4 last weeks the Rt varies little and remains within the range 22-28. So zero chance for the first 3 options, as no strict containment measures are envisaged that would massively reduce the number of contatcs. To refine my prognosis for the last two options, I looked at the variability of Rt over the last two weeks in each state using the following curves (source: https://rt.live/)
I tried to answer the following question: in how many states has Rt varied in the last 3 weeks by going under or over 1? The list:
- California, Virginia, Oklahoma,Idaho, Connecticut=5
In which states > 1 or <1 is guaranteed because it is far from the limit and has little variability?
<1:xxxx xxxx xxxx xxxx xxxx xxxx xxxx=28
>1:xxxx xxxx xxxx xxxx xx=18 The probability of 5/5 of those who vary around 1 in recent weeks stabilizing above 1 exist because today it happens, and people meet more indoors this holiday season.

12/27 there are 23 states with Rt>1, where will it be in 2 weeks?
I am afraid it's GAME OVER.
23 today. Holidays increasing it? Reporting lag over the holidays? Otherwise: trend down.
The number of states with an Rt of 1.0 or greater continues to decrease, it seems very possible that there will be fewer than 23 by Jan. 11th.

12/23 there are 26 states with Rt>1.0 and we have not yet hit the biggest holidays. 
Expect an increase first week of January.
There's 26 of them now, and the holiday season is here.
Same idea, just playing it safe.

"23 or more" still looks to be the most likely outcome.  But new infections appear to be peaking, at least temporarily, so I'll put a few chips on lower ranges.  Christmas and New Year gatherings could make mincemeat of my forecast.
Covid 19 is spreading rapidly and that isn't changing any time soon
Updated slightly exaggerated as I haven’t paid enough attention to this one

Less than a month to go and changes are not happening very quickly. I'm raising my forecast 5% that there will be 23 or more states at or above 1.0. It seems like Pfizer vaccine may quickly reduce the Rt but with 3 weeks between the shots it is probably not going to reduce the rate fast enough  for many states now above 1.0 to fall below before Jan. 11.
With Christmas and New Year coming, and Winter setting in, the likelihood that the Rt will fall in so many states, and stay there, seems unlikely.

12/7 there are 40 states with Rt > 1.0 
This number can be fluid, but right now.

12/3 = 40 states have Rt of 1.0 or greater - but about 19 states are below 1.1
11/25= 39 states have Rt of 1.0 or greater a dramatic change in less than a week. 
Next week we could easily have 30 states and a week after that have 20 states.
Without discipline, we could also easily be back at 48 states on Jan 15.

It seems unlikely that fewer than 23 states will have an Rt above 1.0 by January 11. The number of states has increased significantly since the beginning of this challenge and even though the number is less over the last couple of months it doesn't seem that the changes are occurring fast enough to be below 23 by mid January. This is especially true since going into the holiday season, the population as a whole seems determined to continue gathering in groups with many not wearing masks. I expect things to start changing after mid January when the New Years Eve fallout declines. I actually think the chance is probably better than 90% that there will be more than 23 states above Rt 1.0 but since I'm not sure how I would refine the estimate any better I will be conservative. I will think about refining up or down in a couple of weeks,

I am not sure of what to do with the numbers: there are about 40 days till the deadline for the question, and after a peak like the one that we have now a valley should follow. The number of states with Rt>0 has indeed began to fall, but it is not clear whether this might be noise or the origin of a trend. My bet is for a trend, yet with bad weather controlling the pandemic is notably more difficult: that is, we could end up with a smaller valley that just after the summer and for a shorter time. Thus I have decided to go against the crowd for the moment, at least till I am able to see whether there is a pattern or not.
11/25= 39 states have Rt of 1.0 or greater a dramatic change in less than a week. This can be a fluid number.
The crowd gives "23 or more" a 97% chance.  I don't think it's a slam dunk, so I'll move some chips to lower bins.
11/22= 48 states have Rt of 1.0 or greater.

Rt live is tricky, and has actually had states with less than 1.0 during the height of the second wave in July. The rate of new infections had started to decrease. For example, it listed FL as having dropped below a 1.0 starting 1 July, despite the state recording over 15,000 cases on 12 July. So at this point, I'm not quite ready to rule out less than 23 states.

Assuming that the virus continues unchecked with the White House endorsing herd immunity.  States are limited to what they can do and will be acting independent of each other.  Red states will continue to under report and under test.  Other factors like virus fatigue and continued political polarization of masks make containment unlikely for a significant amount of the US
This does not appear to be a contest.

I'm a little perplexed about the crowd forecast on this one, but don't feel confident enough to go strongly against it for now - after the summer spike we saw a large number of states drive their Rt below 1 as new restrictions were put in place (mask mandates, business closings, etc.) and people generally limited their movement/increased their adherence to social distancing policies in response to the dramatic rise in cases/deaths.  The current trajectory implies things could get *very* bad within the next month - why wouldn't we see the same effect? Will we all really just sit on our hands and watch cases and deaths increase by double digit percentage points every week from now until January? My gut says no, but then again I wouldn't have anticipated that so many people would be actively denying what's going on / encouraging others to ignore public health recommendations...

10/24 - 47 states have a number greater than 1.0. To get to 22 we need to cut that in half in 3 months.
3 months ago it was only 14. The number goes UP faster than it comes down. It takes work and discipline to bring it  down, something people aren't used to doing.

With elections then holiday season coming up and 45 states currently at or above 1.0, it doesn't seem very possible that the number of states over 1.0 have will be less than 23 by Jan 11.  I'm going with 100% above 23 for now. The rate changes rather quickly so it is possible there will be a substantial change right after the New Years celebrations.

10/17 - 44 states have a number greater than 1.0. To get to 22 we need to cut that in half in 3 months.
3 months ago it was only 17. What went wrong?
Oct 16th: 41 states are above 1. Also 7 day average of new cases is increasing, that means the Rt will move further up. I will be stay heavy in bin 5 till I see improvement

https://us.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/10/15/trump-claim-cdc-masks-sot-lead-tapper-vpx.cnn I'm not sure if raising the eyebrows is the right reaction - how can a man be pretending to be this stupid?
The oath and stuff... So where should this question probably be ending?
10/13 there are 39 states above 1.0.  Wash your hands, keep your distance and wear a mask ....please.

There is a noticeable disconnect right now between the crowd forecast for this question and a very similar one here: https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1804-how-many-u-s-states-will-have-a-1-0-or-greater-effective-reproduction-number-rt-for-covid-19-as-of-31-december-2020
Rt has stubbornly held above 0.99 in 23 or more states since early August.  I'll bet that it won't go below 23 until well after Jan 11, 2021, when a vaccine becomes widely available.

Flu season seems to hit pretty hard by mid-December.   I don't think we will be moving in a positive direction at that point in the calendar cycle. Think of all the kids who are potentially asymptomatic who will be traveling home from college for holiday break. Even if our numbers improve by then (which I think is unlikely), you could see a spike in January due to Thanksgiving and Christmas shifts in how people congregrate.
Right now about 37 states have R1 greater than 1. It seems highly unlikely that this number will go down substantially baring a vaccine. But, a vaccine before January seems incredibly unlikely.

The number has doubled since this challenge began. It will likely increase some level off and maybe begin to decline especially if an effective vaccine becomes available. I don't expect the decline to be rapid because the availability and use of the vaccine is likely to be spotty at first and those who are the biggest spreaders because they won't wear a mask etc. are likely to be the last to get vaccinated.

Skewing more toward the higher end. Just eyeballing the trends it appears like most are oscillating or holding fairly steady around 1.0, but looking at the numbers from the last few months it seems anything under 17 is pretty unlikely. No confidence on this one and still a few months left for things to change.

9/28 there are 30 states with Ro greater than 1. Who'd of thought? Two months ago there were half that many.
What happened? Jan 11, will be just enough time for year-end holiday gatherings to trigger another round of infections. People are not learning fast enough how to protect themselves. I don't see that behavior changing.
Sep 26th: Currently Rt is above 1 in 33 states

This challenge ends in 3 1/2 months (108 days).  Rt has not been below 1.0 in less than 8 states since late April.  Since then the number of states with Rt < 1.0  has varied between 15 and 45.  Without a vaccine I believe it will remain within that range. What is the likelihood of a vaccine being widely distributed by the end of 2020?  According to articles such as this one in the Financial Times, it's not very likely. https://www.ft.com/content/e5012891-58da-4a4f-8a05-182adf3ba0e2 Without a vaccine the highest probability should be "23 or more."  I'll put 71% odds on it vs 58% for the crowd.
Sep 23rd: Currently Rt is above 1 in 28 states
The infection rate is likely to worsen over the winter months.
Switching to a barbell distribution, betting that things will either be bad or not so bad.  OK, it's not a very evenly weighted barbell.

We appear to be in a seasonal increase with R0 for many states - will it peak in October and taper off in January?
Sept 16 there are 27 states greater than 1.0 - Up from last month due to final summer holidays and events.
Aug 18 there were 21 who meet the criteria, down from 40 some 3 months ago. 
The target is 4 months out when the US will be in peak flu season which may exacerbate Covid-19 infections. Most states exhibit an L shaped curve, with exceptions that are more like a W. As the disease progresses thru the population the R could decline.

My thought process isn't very precise. Basically that states will be working to keep R0 at or slightly below 1.0. So the most likely answer is in the neighborhood of 50% of "States" (which inexplicably now includes DC but not the other things that aren't states by any reasonable definition of the word. It's a different list every time. Why?). Also that the spread is likely to skew toward the low side because people are targeting less than 1.0. And finally I'm noting that the buckets are not all the same size so need adjustment.

Just over 3 weeks ago there were 18 states that met this criteria. None of them have dropped below 1.0, but 15 others have joined them, putting the total at 33. Many states continue to reopen, schools are returning to in person classes, there remains no comprehensive and coordinated testing system at the federal level, large public gatherings, events, and parties are becoming more common and acceptable, and there is evidence that many Americans have grown bored of worrying about the pandemic. All of these means more people will likely get it, spread it, and die from it, suggesting the Rt value is unlikely to drop below 1.0 in many of the states currently struggling without the release of a vaccine or other artificial inhibitor.

Shifting to a more optimistic weighting.  Jan 11 is nearly four months away, and a lot can happen between now and then.  I'm going with the theory that specific resistance will continue to increase, including possibly from a vaccine.  Rt could surprise on the downside.
Currently Rt is above 1 in 30 states
Covid is spreading. It is going to get worse.
Adjusting based on the excellent analysis of @ManuPV. There are currently 31 states with Rt >= 1

At the beginning of a challenge I tend to develop a "theory of the case," and I bet heavily on it.  Within a couple of months that theory often falls apart.  [As the saying goes, "often wrong but never in doubt."]  I need to be much more humble with my initial predictions. At the start of this challenge I bet heavily on the lower brackets, but with four months to go it's way too early to know.  This is especially true given that Rt does not predict the level of infections.  It's only a crude estimate (which is later revised as subsequent data is used to smooth the curve) of the rate of growth of the virus.  You can have a high level of infections and a low Rt, or a low level of infections and a high Rt. Given the above I'm going to spread out my bets, as the crowd has already done.  At least I won't be 100% wrong, whatever the outcome.

Based on @ManuPV data and combining with new case trend over last 6 months, the bins for this question can be understood as follows:
Bin 5 - Trend of new cases is either flat, slightly up or strongly up
Bin 4 - Trend of new cases slightly down
Bin 3 - Trend of new cases strongly down
Bin 2 & Bin 1 - Everyone has been vaccinated

We are starting to exit summer with 23 states at or above 1.0. As people start to move more activities indoors, and more social distancing fatigue sets in, I don’t see a lot of opportunity for a major long-term reduction. There will be some movement in the number of states, but I think even if the count is much less in the next month, it will creep back up through November and December, hovering at or slightly above 20 in January.

30 August update: Currently 20 states with Rt at or above 1.0 [1]. Nationally, daily positive cases are falling [2]. I largely agree with the reasoning of @jainsa and @Calgacus. I think the crowd is vastly underestimating the number of states that are likely to have a Rt of 1 or greater in January. [1] https://rt.live/
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive

I base this on the likelihood of ongoing disregard of CDC guidelines, which is higher is some states (predominantly in the south and mid-west, with notable exceptions in high income areas in NY & CA). There have been multiple incidents of large-scale parties, gatherings, celebrations that are happening in these areas, and are inevitably followed by the identification of these same gatherings as clusters.

Think of Rt in terms of trend of active cases. When the number of active cases is falling, Rt is below 1, When the number of active cases is increasing Rt is above 1. i.e. currently NY case trend is flat so the Rt is 1, AZ case trend is downwards so the Rt is 0.87 Considering that covid case remains active for ~ 2 week, The question can be reread as follows for better clarity: - In how many states will the biweekly trend of active cases be downwards as of January 11th? Currently in the US, over the last 30 days the trend of active cases has been strongly pointing downwards still we have 18 states with Rt above 1.  I am expecting the trend to be flattish in January. Which means, more than 18 states will have Rt above 1 @juancambeiro , @cdob63 I will like to get your feedback on my above reasoning

Currently 18 [1]. Nationally, daily positive cases are falling [2]. Even if the pandemic is largely under control in the U.S. by January, I think the crowd is overestimating the probability of Rt being below 1 in most states. It doesn't take much for the Rt to be above 1, even when the transmission is largely under control! Also note that 11 January is soon after the holidays  — when we can probably expect a lot of maskless indoor gatherings. [1] https://rt.live/
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive
Lowering my estimates due to the abbot labs test news well summerized by @JamesEE  Still cautious over the inherit volatility of Rt as a measure though

Abbott Labs has received FDA emergency use authorization for a new 15-minute rapid test for COVID. See https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-26/abbott-gets-ok-on-5-15-minute-covid-test-that-avoids-lab-delay Abbott plans to make 50 million tests a month at a cost of $5 per test, and has built two new facilities to ramp up manufacturing. This will increase the number of tests performed by at least a factor of two. Possibly more important is that the test results will be available very quickly so that people can quarantine before infecting more people. If the new infection rate can be greatly reduced, Rt should be below 1.0 in most places.  One open question is the when part.  Will there be millions more tests by January 2021?  I'm going to bet that there will be significantly more testing before the end of 2020, and that Rt will be driven down.

Currently 17 [1]. Nationally, daily positive cases are falling [2]. [1] https://rt.live/
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive

Currently 18 [1]. Nationally, daily positive cases are falling [2]. [1] https://rt.live/
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-daily-positive
Flu season impacts this projection, making it more challenging. I am projecting increased reproduction across states.

Rt can only be estimated, and it turns out not that precisely.  Compare the numbers for July 23, when Rt.live estimated that there were 39 states with Rt >= 1.00.  [I save the web pages so that I can check the old data.]  Today, August 23, the Rt for one month ago is 18.  The number of states with Rt >= 1.00 decreased by over 50%.  On any given day the Rt values are only first estimates, and they can change dramatically over time as more information becomes available.  The errors bands are widest for the first estimates. This challenge is to guess the first estimates of the mean values for Rt on January 11, 2021, with later revisions not affecting the answer.  So it probably doesn't pay to put all our eggs into one basket.  It also indicates that the endpoints could be good bets.  It doesn't matter if the number is 23 or 43, the answer to the question is the same. I'll start with a prediction heavily favoring the higher brackets, especially the open-ended one -- "23 or more."  I'll underweight "7 or fewer," which the crowd heavily favors.   I hope that is the correct answer, since it would indicate that the virus will be going away fast at that time.  But I won't bet on it, at least not yet.

At the moment, there are 18 states with an estimated Rt at or over 1.0 according to https://rt.live/. However, all but 2 states (Alabama and Arizona) have 1.0 within the margin of error for their estimations, meaning the number over 1.0 right now could potentially be as high as 48 out of 50 states. Moreover, many states have leveled out near the 1.0 mark (either above or below) in recent months as shelter in place orders have been lifted and reopening has begun. Both the federal government and many state governors have openly denounced the idea of shutting down the economy again, meaning that these numbers are unlikely to decrease very soon. In fact, it appears the only real precaution still in effect is the social norm of mask wearing, which is still not required by federal law or, indeed, openly encouraged by many state and federal politicians. Moreover, the WHO has just announced it hopes the pandemic to be over in... 2 years. This signals that we are unlikely to see a sudden drop to 0 any time soon without policy changes and more aggressive mitigation techniques.
As such, I believe it will likely remain around current levels for the coming months, with potential random fluctuations up and down due to random error and unforeseen events (ex: school reopenings, large public gatherings, etc.) that could have detrimental effects on local communities.
CT, DE, HI, KA, ME, PR, SD, WY
Covid will get worse in the winter.Chances are best that between 13 and 22 states will be higher than one.

I don't have much confidence so I'm just shifting the distribution slightly lower than where we are now. January 11th is probably too soon for a vaccine to be distributed and having much effect, and winter indoor conditions could increase spread. But cases are trending down and that's long enough from now for any problems associated with spread through school to have been mostly addressed.

Case per 100k correlates roughly -.5 w/ Rt. The best correlation I could find. Currently,
A) 1/2 states w/ rt under median cases/100k for states w/ Rt => 1 have Rt =>1,
B) 1/3 states under median cases per 100k for states w/ Rt<1 have Rt=>1,
C) 1/4 remaining states have Rt=>1. Boldly assuming causation from the correlation noted above, I think the condition C is likely to decline due to continuing slow increase in cases driving Rt down. Assuming roughly 10%-15% of total cases in each state are active (probably more like 8% high numbers feel more conservative here), we should can estimate the expected cases in 140 days based on Rt^(140/10 day transmissable period)*cases*.1 or .15. Also assumed about a 50% regression to mean on all Rts in this calculation. Anyway, then we see we need to apply rule A to 13 states and rule B to 26 states. 13*.5+26*.33 and we end up with 15 or 17 depending on if we used 10 or 15%. If you read all this, good for you :)

The nature of Rt makes this particularly tricky value to predict, as it is calculated by how many people someone passes the infection on to. [1] Even if covid is under control in a state one super spreader event can raise this number significantly. For this reason I’m not going to pay too much attention to predicting numbers of infections in given states, and take a cautious approach. I’m going to start with a base of 25 states having a value greater than 1. (not to far off where we are just now) Factors which could raise Rt :
Increased indoor time as weather gets colder
Travel for the holidays (although may not be fully reflected on Jan 11th)
Decreased social distancing and mask use as people become fatigued/complacent Factors which could decrease Rt:
More effective counter measures such as mass testing (I’m placing a significant amount of hope on this one,as we learn more about the virus and peoples behaviours in the pandemic every day)
Increased immunity in the population (or at least the population who still partake in high risk activities)
Effective vaccine (Unlikely in the time period of the prediction) [1] https://rt.live/faq

Rt live fluctuates between 17-27 states. In Jan 2021, winter, family gatherings from Christmas/New Years, combined with exhaustion from social distancing skews the forecast upwards. Even if a vaccine passes Stage 3, it may not be widely available by then based on historic new vaccine manufacturing/distribution.

It's hard or nearly impossible to predict the R(t) ratio five months ahead of the end date. What is possible now is to determine those events or dates that will have a foreseeable influence on the R(t) by and large of that specific date, 11 January 2021.
It will be pre-christmas travel, maybe pre-christmas brick-and-mortar shopping, beginning season of winter travel (snow season in Colorado, sunny season in Florida, retired "snow birds" traveling north to south), family gatherings around christmas and, not least, New Year's Evening parties, combined with travel back to colleges and universities post-holidays, and with the first-on-record flu season+COVID-19.
All this spells disaster, if people care little or forget the lessons learned 2020. The virus will have it easy to travel interstate across the nation with all the expected travel in any age group. And the virus will have it easy to be transmitted, since people in whatever social group will spend much time not "physically distanced" and indoors. With that in mind I should have opted for the highest bin "23 or more", because all new community transmissions and new outbreaks caused by travel will have just exactly fed into R(t) when this question will be resolved. However, let's see how things develop first, and what the next month brings in news about possible vaccines.

The Rt rate is kind of an odd measure to predict. Looking through the website FAQ, it's clear that what it is measures is the rate at which the number of cases is increasing. If a state has 1 person infected and that person infects 6, the state's Rt is 6, whereas a state that has 10000 cases and 1000 new cases has an Rt of .1. So we're not predicting cases but the rate of infections given the caseload. For example, NH has hovered around .9 to 1 for the past 4 months despite averaging like 60 new cases a day. NJ has been at exactly 1 despite being at 1/3 of their max cases.  Given how far out we are, I think it's reasonable to take a cautious view. Even if the virus is under control, it's very possible for some states to have sky high r1 just if one person goes out partying with coronavirus.

1) The biology of the virus does not change to become less infective and if anything could POSSIBLY evolve to become more infective although this is unlikely.  2) Human nature can change which includes social distancing measures and mask wearing.  3) With school returning in the fall we will have altered some of these human measures to reduce reproductive rate. 4) Infections will continue to occur into the coming year. 5) I foresee an overall increase of knowledge and normalcy in implementing human behavior changes which will likely decrease the number of states that have a >1.0 Rt than what we have now but as history has shown us thus far, states may bounce back and forth.  6)  Number of states will likely be less than 20 but I doubt the number of states to be less than 8 which would indicate a fizzling out of the pandemic in >42 states.  Also, with increased infections, we presumbably have increased immunity, further decreasing Rt but I believe that that we would need a much higher Rt to induce herd immunity within 5 months.

It's almost impossible to continue at +1 for very long...you start running out of people to infect in about 2-3 months.  Texas case is useful to see the numbers.  The narrative is that TX cases are EXPLODING because the the state recklessly opened early.  TX is averaging something like 70k tests daily, and can barely keep it at 1.  So even when testing everybody who will hold still, even though hospitalization rates are dropping, the RT has trouble holding up.  There would have to be a colossal second wave and mass reinfections in order to keep us in the positive range. see https://rt.live/us/TX.   There is a number issue that may play out though.  If enough people decide they don't want to get tested for no reason, then the tests drop back to only people that are symptomatic.  Once that happens, all the rates go up based on a smaller testing pool biased towards probable carriers.  So there's a chance of a big number...but not likely.

Aug 18 there are 21 who meet the criteria, down from 40 some 2 months ago. New cases are slowing reducing Rt.
The target is 5 months out when the US will be in peak flu season which may exacerbate Covid-19 infections. Most states exhibit an L shaped curve, with exceptions that are more like a W. As the disease progresses thru the population the R should decline, unless reinfection is rampant. Currently reinfection is the exception, not the rule.

Most States seem to be pertubating around 1. So I deem all outcomes more or less equally likely. I think the chances of having a vaccine with an impact on R0 are about 1% , therefore 7 or fewer is most likely...

Being through their "worst fall ever" with regards to public health, on the one hand there will be some limited form of natural herd immunity (maybe 30 to 40% of total US population will have had a COVID-19 infection by January 2021, confirmed or unconfirmed), on the other hand limited approved vaccine trials (up to 5% of total US population) could bring about some protection, while at the same time anyone who is neither immune nor vaccinated by that time will look after himself very carefully, as more and more damage done by an infection to the body will be known, and new SARS-CoV-2 strains might complicate things, by causing more harmful or more aggressive infections.
